awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: vObjects - Understanding their Utility to Enhance Learning of Abstract and Complex Engineering Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
Thermodynamics is a subject that often features engineering problems that are not well-defined and abstract concepts that are often hard for students to understand. In addition, the scale at which thermodynamic phenomena occur makes it difficult, if not impossible, for students to interact with authentic physical objects that exhibit such phenomena. To address these challenges, this project will use virtual objects (vObjects) to enhance learning by closely mapping the learner experience to real-life engineering scenarios. This study will be one of the first to systematically evaluate characteristics and features of a virtual learning environment designed to support the "messiness" of real world problem solving.

This project will employ technological advancements for manipulation of vObjects to help students apply foundational knowledge to the solution of ill-defined problems and to address the improvement of virtual learning for future engineering curricula. A comprehensive understanding of the utility of vObjects in engineering will contribute to the development of online learning environments, including augmented reality environments. Virtual learning of engineering skills can also be used as a tool for broadening participation in STEM by providing the opportunity for greater access by diverse students. In broad terms, this research will contribute to improving and transforming undergraduate engineering education by enhancing student learning of theoretical and abstract engineering concepts.

por.por_cntn:
When used appropriately, physical objects can enhance student learning of abstract engineering concepts. Thermodynamics is one of the courses that is taught across multiple disciplines in engineering during the second and third year of the engineering curriculum. Thermodynamics concepts are abstract and difficult, with students having a significant number of misconceptions. A wide range of objects (with different scales, complexity, affordance, etc.) are needed to address conceptual understanding in Thermodynamics, which makes it very difficult, if not impossible to use physical objects to enhance student learning. Additionally, in the majority of fundamental engineering courses, including Thermodynamics, students in most instances only solve well-defined problems and have difficulties when asked to address ill-structured problems.

Interactivity and visualization are learning affordances of physical objects, however, in many instances use of physical objects can be restrictive for learning, because of size, cost, safety and other concerns. Consequently, there is a need to design and systematically study virtual objects to enhance engineering education. In recent years, there has been considerable interest in using digital games, virtual experiments, and interactive simulations to enhance engineering education with a range of outcomes. Despite the effort, there is a lack of understanding of how the engagement from digital learning tools translates into higher order learning skills that are necessary to solve ill-structured problems. It is possible that physical objects activate processes different from those used in virtual environments. To transform engineering education using virtual environments and objects, in this project we addressed the following key research question: How engineering students relate to virtual objects to translate foundational knowledge to ill-structured real-world problems? This focal scientific question, grounding this research, allowed us to situate the utility of objects used in virtual learning environments and lead to effectively use objects in contemporary experiential learning engineering education. Answering our research key question can motivate a systematic and cultural shift towards a project-based approach with vObjects to enhance learning of abstract and difficult engineering concepts for solving ill-structured problems.

This research study helped us understand the nature of interactions between engineering students and virtual objects and how students utilize virtual objects in the completion of ill-structured engineering tasks. Completing the project, we accomplished all of the project aims: 1). Investigated a virtual learning environment with vObjects to enhance learning of abstract and difficult concepts in thermodynamics; 2). Evaluated the affordances of a virtual learning environment designed to support ill-structured problem solving; 3). Identified which characteristics of the virtual learning environment facilitates ill-structured problem solving; 4).  Identified if individual differences in spatial skills and demographics influence students’ interaction with virtual objects; 5). Synthesized and disseminated the project findings; 6). Formulated a long-term agenda to incorporate the use of vObjects and virtual environments in engineering fundamental courses.

Our virtual objects (vObjects) research project contributed to situated learning by closely mapping the learner experience to a real-life scenario. The primary contribution of this research is to directly improve and transform undergraduate engineering education by enhancing student learning in one of the most difficult and abstract engineering subjects. We first assessed if virtual objects are a reasonable replacement for physical objects in such an environment and second, we determined what factors influence the quality of a virtual learning environment. The findings from this study are one of the first to systematically evaluate characteristics and affordances of a virtual learning environment designed to support ill-structured problem solving. Further, we first evaluated the use of real objects and then transfered these characteristics to virtual objects for situated learning. Advances in technology allowed us to improve how virtual learning is done in the future. Furthermore, there is a shortage of good laboratory experiences for engineering students - the virtual learning environment (vObjects) is of value in traditional education as well and in a variety of energy science fundamental engineering courses.

Improving virtual and online means to enhance engineering education can provide a significant benefit to society. The main goal of this research was to understand how virtual objects in eLearning environments enhance students’ ability to apply difficult and abstract engineering concepts to solve ill-structured problems. A comprehensive understanding of the utility of virtual objects in engineering can contribute to the development of online engineering learning environments, including augmented reality environments that closely mimic the use of objects to increase engagement and retention. Increasing participation in STEM by encouraging more virtual learning of engineering skills by definition can broaden participation. The evaluation strategies further provided a variety of opportunities for new research efforts to develop next generation STEM curricula for eLearning environments integrated with effective experiential learning.
